Situation1: The meeting will cover key project updates that won’t be summarized elsewhere.
Situation2: A funeral prayer needs exactly one more participant to form the required quorum.
Story: I stared at my phone, the meeting reminder flashing insistently. Today’s team meeting was crucial—our manager had made it clear that the project updates would only be discussed live, and missing out meant falling behind. As a colleague, I was expected to be present, to contribute, to show commitment. But just as I was about to log in, my phone buzzed again. It was David from the synagogue. They needed one more person for the minyan to say Kaddish at a funeral. Without me, the prayer couldn’t happen, and the mourners would be left without the comfort of tradition. My heart pounded. I felt the weight of my team’s expectations, the importance of not letting them down. At the same time, I felt the pull of my faith, the responsibility to my community, and the knowledge that my presence was essential. I sat frozen, torn between two worlds, each demanding something only I could give, and I didn’t know which way to turn.
